repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
## Problem:

- No easy way to hook into:
    - vim.paste
    - vim.ui.x
    - LSP request/response handlers. (No mention of "before" or "after" in `:help lsp`...)
- Hooking into functions is not ergonomic.
    - Not easy to remove temporary hooks (and restore the old one(s)).
    - No visbility/tracing for debugging/performance/checkhealth.

## Solution:
Introduce `vim.on_fun()`, a generic way to "hook into" any function before/after it is called.

This is a powerful escape-hatch to avoid needing to add formal events (autocmds) for every conceivable thing. And it leverages basic Lua features without becoming an "inner platform": it doesn't require consumers to buy-into the platform, they can continue to treat "hooked" functions like normal functions.

Example:

    vim.on_fun(vim.lsp.handlers, 'textDocument/definition', function(fn, args)
      vim.notify('before, yay')
      local rv = fn(unpack(args))
      vim.notify('after, yay')
      return rv
    end)

Fixes #20568
Fixes #22075
Fixes #22323
Fixes #24229
Related: #13977

## Todo

- naming suggestions? (`on_fn`, `on_call`, ...)?
- ✅  implement `:unhook()` ?
- ✅  some way to have visibility into how many of these damn things are hooked into a given function? `on_fun()` has the same risk as "autocmd spam" where a user/plugin accidentally, redundantly registers a handler and overloads the editor.

comment_data.body:
I'm surprised I couldn't find something like this in https://github.com/rxi/lume or https://github.com/luafun/luafun .

Does anyone have a util function like this in their plugins?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1436,6 +1436,41 @@ notify_once({msg}, {level}, {opts})                        *vim.notify_once()*
     Return: ~
         (boolean) true if message was displayed, else false
 
+on_fun({container}, {key}, {fn})                                *vim.on_fun()*
+    Sets function `container[key]` to a new (wrapper) function that, if
+    invoked, calls `fn()` before optionally calling the original ("base")
+    function.

comment_data.body: For what it's worth, there is `pack_len` and `unpack_len` in `vim.F` module that does this
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -948,6 +948,63 @@ function vim._init_defaults()
   vim._init_default_autocmds()
 end
 
+table.pack = table.pack or function(...) return { n = select("#", ...), ... } end

comment_data.body: Should we have a `compat.lua` module where we set `table.pack` (to match Lua 5.2)? Assuming it's "less worse" to use a common Lua 5.2 name instead of a custom name?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -948,6 +948,63 @@ function vim._init_defaults()
   vim._init_default_autocmds()
 end
 
+table.pack = table.pack or function(...) return { n = select("#", ...), ... } end

comment_data.body: 💯 that's two steps closer to killing `F.lua` -- leaves only `vim.F.npcall` as actually used in our codebase, and that could just as well be moved directly under `vim`  to `_editor.lua`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -948,6 +948,63 @@ function vim._init_defaults()
   vim._init_default_autocmds()
 end
 
+table.pack = table.pack or function(...) return { n = select("#", ...), ... } end

comment_data.body:
But note that LuaJIT may be compiled with 5.2 extensions, in which case it already has `table.{un}pack`, so that would have to be checked first.

If we do go that route, we could also (conditionally) add useful extensions from openResty's LuaJIT2 like `table.isempty`, `table.isarray`, `table.nkeys`, and `table.clone` (which means we could deprecate `vim.tbl_isempty` etc., or at least offer LuaJIT2 users access to the compiled version).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -948,6 +948,63 @@ function vim._init_defaults()
   vim._init_default_autocmds()
 end
 
+table.pack = table.pack or function(...) return { n = select("#", ...), ... } end

comment_data.body:
> If we do go that route, we could also (conditionally) add useful extensions from openResty's LuaJIT2 like table.isempty, table.isarray, table.nkeys, and table.clone (which means we could deprecate vim.tbl_isempty etc., or at least offer LuaJIT2 users access to the compiled version).

Sounds appealing. Would this play nicely with luals?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -948,6 +948,63 @@ function vim._init_defaults()
   vim._init_default_autocmds()
 end
 
+table.pack = table.pack or function(...) return { n = select("#", ...), ... } end

comment_data.body:
Instead of this "control via return values" approach, `fn()` could simply take the base function as the first arg, and the parameters are in a `table.pack()` table named `args`.  Then everything is much more natural.

- pro/con of "control via return values" approach:
    - pro: wrapper doesn't need to explicitly call the base function:
      ```
      vim.on_fun(vim, 'paste', function()
        counter = counter + 1
      end)
      ```
    - con: less obvious what's going on, more to explain in docs.
    - con: if the wrapper wants to modify the args, it's less readable/obvious
- pro/con of `fn(basefn, args)` approach:
    - pro: easy and obvious how to modify args, "cancel", or "go after".
    - pro: simpler docs and impl
    - pro: wrapper funcs are future-proof if the base function adds more parameters!
      ```
      basefn(unpack(args))
      ```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2464,6 +2464,73 @@ parents({start})                                            *vim.fs.parents()*
         (function) Iterator
 
 
+==============================================================================
+Lua module: func                                                    *lua-func*
+
+on_fun({container}, {key}, {fn})                           *vim.func.on_fun()*
+    Sets function `container[key]` to a new (wrapper) function that calls
+    `fn()` before optionally calling the original ("base") function.
+
+    The result of `fn()` decides how the base function is invoked. Given `fn()` : >lua

comment_regular_data.body:
I don't think this will solve https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/22075

`vim.lsp.buf.rename` doesn't use the global handlers. Same with `vim.lsp.buf.code_action` and to fix https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/22318 we'll also need to change it to no longer call the global handlers.

The global handlers are fine for server-to-client requests, but for anything else they're not a good match and imho the vim.lsp.with mechanism was a mistake.

- If you have multiple clients, a global handler is called once per client. That's usually not what you want as most operations require some sort of merge first

- Many operations are not a simple request -> response pair, but involve several round-trips. Rename first calls `textDocument/prepareRename` and then `textDocument/rename`. Code actions involve `textDocument/codeAction`, optionally `codeAction/resolve` and then maybe a `workspace/executeCommand`. We need a mechanism that can deal with chained/sequenced actions.

I don't mind having a generic `on_fun` monkey-patching mechanism  but I am fairly sure it's the wrong solution for hooking into LSP response handlers.


I think instead we should:

- Have some kind of future/promise/async-thunk/whatever (relates a bit to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/19624) that each of the `vim.lsp.buf` methods returns that allows to
  a) cancel
  b) use the _synthesized_ result of the operation by being able to attach an additional callback or map the result. This would address https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/18372 and lots of other feature requests.
  c) await (coroutine aware) or get(blocking) the result.

  I already have some local version where I played around with this a bit. There I also have a new `vim.lsp.request` that would replace `buf_request`, `buf_request_all` and `buf_request_sync` and also solve the mixed-encoding warnings.

- Maybe add a `LspResponse` autocmd that's triggered whenever a response is received with `data` set to the payload as a generic listener mechanism.

@mfussenegger great insight, thank you!

> I don't think this will solve #22075 , `vim.lsp.buf.rename` doesn't use the global handlers.

Ok. `on_fun` could be mildly useful for use-cases like "I want to save all files after rename" ...

```
  vim.on_fun(vim.lsp.handlers, 'textDocument/rename', function(...)
    return function()
      vim.cmd.wall()
    end, ...
  end)
```
...but that is arguably better achieved by creating a plain old function:

```
  function my_rename()
    vim.lsp.buf.rename()
    vim.cmd.wall()
  end
```


> The global handlers are fine for server-to-client requests, but for anything else they're not a good match and imho the vim.lsp.with mechanism was a mistake.

Great insight. I will see if I can use that to improve the docs.

Years ago when I suggested `vim.lsp.with` I was imagining something more like `vim.on_fun()`. But it still suffers from the lack of the "synthesized" semantics, as you mentioned.

> I also have a new `vim.lsp.request` that would replace `buf_request`, `buf_request_all` and `buf_request_sync` and also solve the mixed-encoding warnings.

💯

> and imho the vim.lsp.with mechanism was a mistake.

I gotta retract that statement,  or at least refine it: I think for requests that are pushed from servers it's fine. But using it as mechanism to configure user invoked functions is not ideal and I don't see a way to make it generally work for multiple clients or multi-step request sequences. 

That btw. wasn't meant to say I'm against the vim.on_func. It looks like it addresses a separate use-case - although with some overlap. And it's probably an improvement over the lsp.with lsp specific version.

> wasn't meant to say I'm against the vim.on_func. It looks like it addresses a separate use-case

yeah, the parameters you have laid out here are extremely helpful, for the LSP use-case. There are other use-cases like `vim.paste` and `vim.ui` where we currently don't have a great answer for "hooking into without overriding", so it seems like we still need a hook mechanism for those cases.

title: feat(lua): vim.func.on_func()
